G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this action involves residential property located within Worcester County and falls within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this action involves residential property located within Worcester County and falls within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 3.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court under Mass. R. Civ. P. 3 because the events giving rise to the claim occurred in Worcester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 293 N.E.2d 831 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that rodent or pest infestations that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use of leased premises constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Hemingway is a concurrence/dissent focused on implied warranty of habitability and the effect of State Sanitary Code violations on rent obligations. It does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it frame rodent or pest infestation (or any conditions) as a breach of that covenant. Because the opinion section provided neither addresses quiet enjoyment nor uses infestation as an example of such a breach, this case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: I dissent from the statement of such a broad and sweeping new rule for the reason, in part, that it would be sufficient for the decision of these cases to hold that the landlord, in renting the apartments to the tenants, impliedly agreed that the apartments would comply with the several requirements of the Code which the tenants allege were violated, and that if the tenants sustain their burden of proof of such violations their liability for the unpaid rent may be reduced to the fair value of their use and occupancy of the apartments in their deficient condition.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that rodent or pest infestations that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use of leased premises constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard of fault (at least negligence) required for a landlord to be liable for breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, mainly in the context of lead paint violations. It does not address rodent or pest infestations at all, nor does it state that such infestations constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, this case cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition regarding rodent or pest infestations.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 431 N.E..proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that rodent or pest infestations that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use of leased premises constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 431 N.E..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment, explains that it protects tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy, and ties that doctrine to unsanitary housing conditions governed by the State Sanitary Code. While this particular case involved sewage flooding rather than rodents, the court states that the covenant covers conditions that impair the character and value of the premises and links § 14 quiet enjoyment liability to a landlord’s duty to maintain sanitary conditions. This squarely supports the broader principle that substantial pest or rodent infestations interfering with use and enjoyment can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 431 N.E..relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute. … Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 358.proposition: The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from substantial interference by actions or omissions of the landlord that affect the tenant’s ability to use and enjoy the premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 358.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that the landlord breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment where tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment by loud music and disturbances coming from a lounge leased by the landlord, even though the landlord did not intend that result. The court explains that a breach may occur when substantial interference with use and enjoyment is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, so long as the landlord had the right and ability to control the condition. That aligns squarely with the proposition that the covenant protects tenants from substantial interference arising from the landlord’s actions or omissions affecting use and enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 358.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 629 N.E.2d 1343 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that rodent or pest infestations that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use of leased premises constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize that serious interferences with use of leased premises—here, loss of use of common areas due to drug activity—can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. However, it does not involve or discuss rodent or pest infestations at all, nor does it state any rule specific to infestations as a basis for breach. Using this case as authority for a long‑recognized rule about rodent or pest infestations misstates its holding and context.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Meikle v. Nurse, 474 Mass. 207, 49 N.E.3.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that rodent or pest infestations that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use of leased premises constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Meikle v. Nurse, 474 Mass. 207, 49 N.E.3.support_reasoning: Nothing in Meikle v. Nurse addresses rodent or pest infestations, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, or conditions constituting substantial interference with use of leased premises. The case is about whether a violation of the security deposit statute can be asserted as a defense to possession under G.L. c. 239, § 8A. While Meikle briefly cites a different case (Lawrence v. Osuagwu) for a quiet-enjoyment counterclaim, Meikle itself does not establish or discuss the proposition regarding infestations and quiet enjoyment.
Meikle v. Nurse, 474 Mass. 207, 49 N.E.3.relevant_excerpt: See Lawrence v. Osuagwu, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 60, 63 (2003) (interpreting “violation of any other law” to include counterclaim for breach of covenant of quiet enjoyment under G. L. c. 186, § 14). The security deposit statute is one such law.

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 506 N.E.2d 1164 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that rodent or pest infestations that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use of leased premises constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions the presence of mice and ants among various State Sanitary Code violations but does not analyze them as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Instead, the court treats these conditions in the context of warranty of habitability and rent abatement, and expressly notes that most conditions had minimal impact on use and enjoyment. There is no discussion of rodents or pests as constituting, by themselves, a breach of quiet enjoyment, nor any statement of the long‑recognized rule asserted in the proposition.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
"Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property.2 The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs."

"The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks."

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 576 N.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that rodent or pest infestations that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use of leased premises constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 576 N.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions that the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents and clearly treats these conditions as part of serious sanitary code and habitability violations. However, the case does not discuss, analyze, or hold that rodent or pest infestations constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment specifically, nor does it frame this as a long-recognized Massachusetts rule. The decision focuses on warranty of habitability, emotional distress, and Chapter 93A damages rather than articulating any doctrinal rule about quiet enjoyment and infestations, so it does not support the precise proposition cited.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 576 N.relevant_excerpt: “After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: … (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents. … The judge ordered Haddad to repair most of the defects by August 22, 1983. He also ordered Haddad to install a heating system by September 15, 1983, and to have the apartment treated by a professional exterminator.”

Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.raw_text: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512, 789 N.E.2d 147 (2003)
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that rodent or pest infestations that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use of leased premises constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.case_name: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether counterclaims are procedurally allowed in commercial summary process actions and the effect of G.L. c. 239, § 8A; it does not discuss rodents, pests, habitability, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment at all. There is no language recognizing that rodent or pest infestations constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment, so the case cannot be cited as authority for that proposition.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.relevant_excerpt: Because a tenant’s right to bring a counterclaim is explicitly limited in § 8A to premises “rented or leased for dwelling purposes,” it is clear that it applies only to summary process actions in residential cases. Had the Legislature intended § 8A to allow tenant counterclaims in both residential and commercial summary process proceedings, it could have included words to that effect, or omitted the words, “for dwelling purposes.” “We will not add words to a statute that the Legislature did not put there, either by inadvertent omission or by design.”

Service Publications, Inc. v. Goverman,.raw_text: Service Publications, Inc. v. Goverman, 396 Mass. 567, 487 N.E.2d 520 (1986)
Service Publications, Inc. v. Goverman,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that rodent or pest infestations that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use of leased premises constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Service Publications, Inc. v. Goverman,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Service Publications, Inc. v. Goverman concerns contract claims, Chapter 93A unfair business practices, and procedural matters such as judgment notwithstanding the verdict and remittitur. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or conditions of leased premises, nor does it mention rodents, pests, or infestations. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for the proposition about rodent or pest infestations breaching the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199.proposition: Defendant’s neglect of extermination responsibilities, after being informed of persistent infestation, demonstrates a failure to maintain the Premises in habitable condition in violation of G.L. c. 239, § 8A and the reasoning of Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199.
Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199.support_reasoning: This portion of Hemingway is a concurring/dissenting opinion that discusses, in general terms, implied obligations to comply with the State Sanitary Code and the interaction with G.L. c. 239, § 8A, but it does not address extermination duties or a specific fact pattern of ‘persistent infestation’ and landlord neglect. It therefore does not establish the specific principle that a landlord’s failure to exterminate after notice constitutes a breach of habitability under § 8A. At most, it supports the broader idea that violations of the State Sanitary Code can amount to a failure to maintain habitable premises, but not the narrow proposition quoted.
Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: The condition of ongoing vermin infestation rendered the apartment partially uninhabitable and interfered with Plaintiff’s health, safety, and comfort, in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.551.

State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. \u00a7 4.proposition: The condition of ongoing vermin infestation rendered the apartment partially uninhabitable and interfered with Plaintiff’s health, safety, and comfort, in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.551.
